answers.answer: For what it's worth, NCV/EMG tests, when done by a COMPETENT doctor's office (like an ALS clinic, a good neurologist, etc.) are VERY good at determining if one has ALS or not.  Especially the EMG, which can only be done by a doctor and is therefore more likely to be quite accurate.Since those tests are fine for you, I wouldn't worry about ALS, but you could have something else (Lyme disease, BFS, etc.).Good luck.
Thanks Perc...I will keep up the hope.  The only thing that concerns me is that I've read that EMGs sometimes come back normal when the ALS onset is Bulbar.....this is all confusing to me in general.

I have been going onto the ms forum for several months, but was recently told that I most likely don't have ms (due to a spinal tap). I did have an EMG 3 weeks ago and it was not done by a doctor. I guess that should be a concern, huh? Please let me know your symptoms/history.

question: I'm 40 and starting to get confused (perhaps a bit scared too).I've started getting twitches and fasciculations in my arms and abdomen.  This is after I was experiencing crampyness in my calf and upper arm muscles,  arm/hand/shoulder fatigue, and overall fatigue (tiredness).  Naturally this pointed me to ALS when doing on-line research.  I had blood glucose testing (for diabetes) and an NCV/EMG last week which came back with no problems.  They tested mostly on one hand and forearm.  I seem to be getting more fatigued by the day.  I'm concerned that the EMG test is not reliable and that I should be retested.  Is this a valid issue....what else can I do (have a MRI scheduled in 2weeks) and what should I be looking for.
title: Fasciculations
